I take the arm. I save your life. And in return, you give me the story. All of it. No lies. No holding back. You tell me how a man's hand turns to stone and ash. That's the deal."

It was a mad bargain, struck at the edge of the abyss. A story for a life. A truth for a salvation. It was the only currency Arthur had left. "Yes," he gasped. "Anything. I'll tell you everything." Skinner nodded, satisfied. The bargain was struck. "Good," he said, his voice returning to its brisk, professional tone. He grabbed a dusty, unopened bottle of cheap whisky from a shelf. "You're going to need this." He uncapped it and handed it to Arthur. "Drink. As much as you can, as fast as you can. Don't stop until I tell you." He then produced a thick, worn leather strap, the kind used for sharpening razors. "And this. When I start, you bite down on this. It's better than breaking your teeth."

Arthur took the bottle with his shaking left hand and drank, the raw, fiery liquid burning a path down his throat and hitting his empty stomach like a fist of flame. He coughed and sputtered, but he drank again, forcing the alcohol down, seeking the oblivion it promised. The room began to swim, the edges blurring. Through the alcoholic haze, he saw Skinner wrap the thick rubber tube around his upper arm, a makeshift tourniquet, and cinch it brutally tight, cutting off all blood flow. The pressure was immense, a crushing, agonizing vise. Arthur cried out, a muffled gasp. "Bite," Skinner commanded, holding out the leather strap. Arthur took it, clamping his teeth down on the tough, worn leather. Skinner then took Arthur’s arm and laid it flat on a steel tray attached to the chair, positioning the angry red line directly under the unforgiving beam of the surgical lamp. He picked up the saw. Its cold, clean weight felt purposeful, absolute. "Don't move," he said, his voice the last clear thing in Arthur’s swimming, terrified consciousness. He placed the cold, serrated edge of the blade against the inflamed skin on Arthur’s forearm, just above the wrist. The teeth bit into his flesh, and with a grunt of pure, professional effort, the world dissolved into a single, unending scream of white-hot agony.

The first drag of the saw was a line of pure, liquid fire drawn across his skin. Arthur’s entire nervous system, already screaming from a dozen other wounds, focused into a single, white-hot point of violation. His muffled scream was swallowed by the thick leather strap, his jaw aching with the pressure. The room, which had been swimming in a whisky-fuelled haze, snapped into a terrifying, preternatural clarity. He saw every detail of Skinner’s face, the beads of sweat on his furrowed brow, the intense, professional concentration in his pale blue eyes. He saw the fine spray of his own blood misting the air. The rasp of the steel teeth against his flesh was a dry, tearing sound, a counterpoint to the wet, thudding drum of his own heart.

Then the blade hit bone. The sound changed from a soft, wet tearing to a hard, grating shriek, a sound that vibrated not just in his ears, but up the entire length of his arm and into his skull. It was the sound of a living structure being unmade, of a framework being systematically destroyed. The shock of it was a physical blow, a concussive force that rattled his teeth and made his vision flicker and strobe. Skinner grunted with the effort, his powerful shoulders bunching as he put his weight into the stroke. This was the true horror, the part the whisky couldn't touch. This was not a wound; it was a deconstruction, a methodical and brutal dismantling of the self, and he was awake for every terrible second of it.

His mind, unable to process the sheer, overwhelming volume of pain, fractured. It fled the roaring present and tumbled back through time. For a moment, he was not in a grim tattoo parlour in the Hythe, but back in the cluttered quiet of his study. He saw the dust motes hanging in the buttery afternoon light, a galaxy of tiny, unmoving worlds. He felt the vellum of the Corinium Manuscript beneath his fingers, its promise of peace so beautiful and pure. The Principle of Reciprocal Empathy. A terrible name. The grating of the saw became the scraping of his chair against the floorboards as he pushed back in his moment of discovery. The face of Magnus, the long-dead philosopher, flickered behind his eyes, its features shifting and melting into the focused, sweating face of Skinner, both of them architects of his fate, both of them revealing a terrible, hidden truth about the nature of the world.

The ordeal seemed to stretch into an eternity, each back-and-forth stroke of the saw a lifetime of agony. He was no longer a man, no longer Arthur Penwright, the classics tutor. He was just a knot of screaming nerve endings, a consciousness trapped in a cage of torment. The leather strap was a gag, the chair a rack, the surgical lamp an inquisitor’s hostile star. He felt a profound, animal desire to flee, to tear himself away from the chair, but the tourniquet and Skinner’s iron grip held him fast. He was a sacrifice upon a steel altar, and the pain was the liturgy. He saw Albright’s face then, smiling that cold, triumphant smile, and a surge of pure, black rage gave him a final, fleeting burst of strength. It was not enough. The saw bit deeper, a final, jarring crunch echoing through his very bones.

And then, release. A sudden, shocking cessation of the grinding, vibrating agony. The dead weight of his right arm, the carbonised claw that had been his brand and his curse, was gone. For a single, blessed moment, there was a void, a hollow space where the pain had been. It was immediately filled by a new, different kind of pain: a clean, throbbing, volcanic heat from the raw, open wound of his stump. He gasped, the leather strap falling from his mouth, his lungs dragging in a great, shuddering breath that tasted of blood and alcohol. Through the swimming haze of his vision, he saw Skinner drop the saw into a metal basin with a sharp clatter. The dead hand, attached to the severed portion of his forearm, lay on the steel tray, a grotesque and alien artifact. It was over. The thought was a prayer. But it wasn't. Skinner picked up the butane torch, and with a click and a hiss, a brilliant blue flame roared to life. He was not finished. He had to close the wound.

The searing heat of the flame against his raw flesh was a new dimension of hell, a pain so absolute and elemental it defied description. The smell of his own cooking flesh filled his nostrils, a thick, greasy, nauseating stench. This final, brutal act of cauterisation was the blow that finally severed the last thread connecting his consciousness to his body. The world did not fade to black; it shattered into a million points of light and then ceased to exist altogether. The last thing he knew was the deep, guttural sound of Skinner’s voice, tight with effort. "Almost there," it said, a promise from a world he had already left behind.

He awoke to the slow, rhythmic throbbing of his own mutilated body. The pain was no longer a white-hot scream but a deep, oceanic pulse that seemed to move in time with his heartbeat. He was lying on his side, on a narrow cot, a rough woollen blanket scratching against his cheek. The air smelled different, cleaner, the overpowering stench of burned flesh having been replaced by the sharp, sterile scent of antiseptic. He opened his eyes. He was in a small, windowless storeroom, shelves stacked with boxes of ink and needles lining the walls. A single, bare bulb hanging from a wire cast a dim, yellow light over the cramped space. He was alive.

He pushed himself up into a sitting position, his head pounding with the mother of all hangovers, his body a single, unified ache. He looked down at his right arm. It ended just below the elbow in a thick, expertly wrapped bandage of clean white gauze. The dead hand was gone. The physical manifestation of his impossible journey, the brand of his power and his failure, was no more. He was permanently, irrevocably diminished. The sight of the neatly bandaged stump did not bring a fresh wave of horror, but a profound, hollow sense of finality. He had survived, but the man who had walked through walls, the man who had held the cure for war, had been amputated along with the limb. What was left was just Arthur Penwright, a broken scholar with one hand.

The door to the storeroom creaked open, and Skinner entered. He had cleaned himself up, his face washed, his arms wiped clean of blood. He held a steaming mug in his tattooed hands. He said nothing, simply walked over and placed the mug on a small crate beside the cot. It was cheap, instant coffee, but the rising steam was the most comforting sight Arthur had ever seen. Skinner pulled the crate over and sat down, his large frame seeming to fill the small room. He looked at Arthur, his pale blue eyes once again cool and appraising. He nodded towards the bandaged stump.

"You'll live," Skinner said, his voice the same low, emotionless gravel as before. "The fever broke about an hour ago. I had to pump you full of black-market antibiotics I keep for emergencies. It was close." He leaned forward, his elbows on his knees, his gaze unwavering. "I did my part. I took the arm. I saved your life. You slept for almost a full day." He paused, letting the silence hang in the air, thick and expectant. Then, he delivered the final part of his diagnosis, and the first part of his demand. "Now you hold up yours. Tell me the story. Tell me what you told me you would. Start at the very beginning. And Arthur," he said, his voice dropping even lower, more intense, "don't even think about lying to me."
